Comment: Is it any wonder? 

http://www.amren.com/news/2015/07/new-doj-statistics-on-race-and-violent-crime/

This table can be used for a number of interesting calculations. First, we find that during the 2012/2013 period, blacks committed an average of 560,600 violent crimes against whites, whereas whites committed only 99,403 such crimes against blacks. This means blacks were the attackers in 84.9 percent of the violent crimes involving blacks and whites. This figure is consistent with reports from 2008, the last year DOJ released similar statistics. Perhaps not coincidentally, that was the year Mr. Obama was elected president.

Interestingly, we find that violent interracial crime involving blacks and Hispanics occurs in almost exactly the same proportions as black/white crime: Blacks are the attackers 82.5 percent of the time, while Hispanics are attackers only 17.5 percent of the time.

Comment: How many of fellow ADN readers have visited Tyonek? I am from the Interior and not a native Alaskan. But, i have visited and worked in Tyonek a couple of times. ... At night, one can hear and see the oil drilling platforms in Cook Inlet. On the walls inside their tribal hall, the drawings/plans for this coal project draws a visitor's attention. I asked the residents about these drawings and they told me of their concerns. The dust, the noise, the salmon streams, the influx of workers, the angst about jobs vs quality of life.How the white folks from Anchorage fly over to kill the local wildlife that they rely upon for subsistence.  But, the most memorable conversation was with a person born and raised there, left to get an education while vowing to come back to help her people. Forgive me that i cannot recall her name, but she is there and is helping that village. I have been to Tyonek as a veterinarian associated with ARVO (Alaska Rural Veterinary Outreach) to offer veterinary care...

Comment: I've always been amazed at the distinction made, or lack of understanding about concealed weapons vs. openly carried weapons.  For concealment to work, the weapon must be smaller, have less capacity,  less range, and overall less effectiveness as an offensive weapon. Concealable weapons are by their nature a defensive weapon.  The defensive nature of the concealed weapon relates directly to the SCOTUS Heller decision which carved out a personal right to firearms for self defense. The 9th Circuit, ignoring of the spirit of Heller, and using 14th-17th century English law  as precedent , thinks that because criminals might conceal their weapons until they can spring an ambush attack, that no one should be able to carry a concealed weapon in public for defense unless they can prove a compelling reason.  The press loves prior restraint when it comes to 2A, and hates prior restraint when it comes to 1A.  Why fear 99% of the public who are law abiding?

Comment: Having spent some 12 1/2 years as a Contracts Officer with the State of Oregon, I have some familiarity with the bidding process.   In addition my father did heavy construction for this type of thing so I grew up with it.  

Each bid request has certain minimum standards which must be met by anyone who wants to bid on the contract.  Assuming those are met, it normally comes down to the "lowest qualified bidder".  

 That is a legal term which has hundreds of thousands of attorney dollars behind its definition.  In this case there were only two bidders and Eugene Sand & Gravel bid $3.4 million so Wildish gets the contract at $2.9 million.  There are many other qualified bidders for this small a job,  but they chose not to bid.  That means $500 thousand was 'left on the table'.  They could have won bidding $3.3 million.

Unlike a lot of States or cities, Oregon's bidding processes have an excellent reputation for not having the graft and political corruption more common elsewhere.

Comment: The federal Constitution has no relevance in this instance irrespective of how many times the attempt is made. We are not discussing the general government seizing the land in Park County to build a water storage facility for a federal military base which would be a necessary and proper exercise of the powers delegated to the general government to provide protection for all of the States belonging to the Union.  No, here we are talking about one city government attempting to seize land in a distant county; not for the benefit of the entire State, but for the sole benefit of the city whose legislative branch contains no representatives from the county they are attempting to seize land in.  Exercise of governmental powers in the absence of representatives from the people subjected to such actions are what led to the formation of our republic.

Comment: Interesting analysis and perspective however, my experience in trade discussions is the notion some must give something up for others to gain  is what creates a watered down negotiations among all parties. Furthermore, although it may be noble to trade with poorer less developed countries, those are historically the same countries that have an inconsistent approach to rule of law, and no investor would want to be subject to justice procedures in countries where they be sued and potentially lose their assets. Investor risk appetite is a main ingredient in any trade deal, and is a determining factor in pursuing countries to negotiate with that no government can get around. Governments are their to protect the interests of their citizens including trade deals.

Comment: During the final years of apartheid and in preparation of a post apartheid South Africa the type of state and form of government was hotly debated. The Inkatha Freedom party under the leadership of Chief Buthelezi favoured a Federal Democracy with a two Chamber National Assembly. The one chamber elected proportionally based on the size of the electorate per province the other one on a individual basis directly by the electorate. The Inkatha Freedom party's aim was to strengthen the provincial and municipal powers by the principle of subsidiarity. The argument was that power should be delegated to the lowest level possible to be effective. Chief Buthelezi was well ahead of his time - but was branded a stooge of the 'Apartheid Regime'. The rest is history and two decades later the chicken come home to roost.

Comment: California rushed it, and we can do better.

I am one of the 2/3's who support legalization, but on the basis it is a measured response.  It is coming, but a society isn't built in a hurry.

The existing supply channel has been operating outside of compliance for too long.  The anonymity and lack of accountability make regulating them impractical.  The only practical answer is to establish a new channel and try to eliminate the existing one.  For those passionate about their industry, join the new channel, or be a customer.

The licensed growers disclose financials, pay taxes, have to treat their workers properly, sign leases or buy buildings and be accountable for property stewardship, grow without poisons, be accountable for their product recalls, etc.  

And we need rules for managing impairment at work or driving etc. as a matter of public safety.  A fundamental charter right is the safety and security of the person.  The legislation needs to cover this.   

Don't rush it.

Comment: You might want to take it as a compliment that I gave you credit for your last link, which actually was credible. As I said, I'm an old scientist, I know early research when I see it. They were researching one election in one locale, a point in time. That seems minor, but it separates science from anecdotal evidence, which is only perception clouded by bias. Now, should other researchers not only confirm the initial research but go on to find similar results in other elections, trends + connections can be established. This 2014 study could lead to confirmation of your perception or it might prove to be an anomaly. Personally, I'm betting on the anomaly. More often than not, a research hypothesis leads to a dead end. That said, this is far better than a he said, she said, I think so just because sort of argument, which was all you had before citing this study. 

The rest of your post is fluff + bluster revealing a lot about you. What really matters are facts and laws, not conjecture.

Comment: Yes Shawn I read the article. This is an opinion from a director in the Wilderness Society with their agenda.  My agenda is strictly Alaskan.  The state didn't build the pipeline but they did build the Haul Road. The federal government built a railroad from Seward to Fairbanks and along the way established a supply camp that eventually became Anchorage. Roads and Rails will determine the economic future of Alaska as well as impact the cost of living in rural locations.

Comment: Catholic parents who want to raise children to value and respect everyone are in a bind. Unless the parents can be assured of the contrary by personally examining the curriculum, philosophy and values of the school or religious education program, they have to assume that a Catholic school or program is hostile to GLBTQ students and families.  If such parents continue to value religious education for their children, they will have to find a way to provide formation for the sacraments that excludes the bigotry of the main program.  Schools and parishes, teachers and pastors, that are trying to be welcoming, inclusive and affirming are walking a precarious tightrope; I don't think it's sustainable.  Home schooling for religious education may be an answer for some families, but this situation does not seem tenable over the long haul.

Comment: I get not liking the alternatives too much, but how do you reach the conclusion that the economy is running well here? The only major bright spot is real estate/construction, which has exploded to become 1/3 of GDP. It's the boom in this one sector that is making everything look "good" economically. But if you look at this "success" in any sort of detail, it sure doesn't look like a win if your goal is to build a sustainable economy that will prosper in the future. The economy is very de-diversified. The Lower Mainland has a growing net loss of people under the age of 45, with 60%+ people reporting a desire to leave the region (which comprises over half the province's population). Business and government leaders in Vancouver, and now Victoria are reporting significant issues attracting and retaining talent. These sorts of problems are not the byproducts of a well run economy. They are what happens when you burn the future to shine today.

Comment: Taking influence from other cultures is hardly appropriation.  It contributes to a shared experience so that we may understand each other better.

If we decide that an artist is only permitted to draw from his/her own heritage for influence, imagine how bleak the creative landscape would be.  Opera would cease to exist, since virtually all of the stories upon which the classics are based are lifted from other cultures .  Goodbye rock'n'roll, blues and jazz.  No more Doric columns in architecture, unbelievably bland food in the kitchens and cafés, and literature confined to the Western experience.

And if we want to get truly ridiculous about the whole thing -- indigenous writing, which sparked this whole non-debate, may be called cultural appropriation of the worst sort.  Few if any indigenous peoples even had a written language -- and the oral traditions did not begin with English.  For shame!

Comment: Hofstader's book was published in 1963, it was not written about 1963. It was a historical exploration of how anti-intellectualism was "cool" pretty much right from the beginning of the U.S. He followed it with an essay in 1964 about how the 'paranoid' style was similarly historically ingrained in American culture and politics. He was not writing about 1964, he was explaining how the paranoia rising in American politics in 1964 was not new and had deep historical roots.

Yellow journalism in major news publications (reaching the many). Local dinners. Zines. Water coolers. Jewish conspiracy. Papal conspiracy. Masonic conspiracy. UFOs. Communists in every corner. Misinformation and paranoia could and did spread very wide and very fast.

Those who lack awareness beyond ten years are prone to believe that somehow what happens today is new and different, bigger and worse. Ultimately, trapped in a their own bubble of misinformation, hyperbole and paranoid belief. Ironic, eh?

Comment: It's like no one pays attention in civics class anymore.  Presidents are elected by the states. The electors give states a say in the election of the president proportional to the population of the state. The US wasn't designed as a pure democracy and for good reasons. They saw even then that a populous state could override the needs and interests of more sparsely populated states. They built safeguards against this tyranny of the majority via the Electoral College and indirect election of Senators who were supposed to primarily represent state interests while the HOR represented citizen interests. The 17th amendment overrode that, and I personally think that while it solved some issues, it had negative consequences.

Comment: Clearly I never denied a certain unpredictability since I in multiple places mentioned our cooperation.   

I reject the word random however for a very substantial reason.

There's more than chance involved.  There's virtue, which is a natural faculty God invented and put in us:  an ability to grow toward the good.  Virtue happens when good acts are repeated, tending to make our response to God's will less random, and more inclined to the good.

People who understand what virtue is (dispositions/habits to do good) and who assiduously work to increase their virtue will on average respond to moral choices toward choosing (and toward doing) the good.

That's not random.

Comment: I’d say it’s further proof that irrational exuberance can be profitable.

Tesla struggles to meet consumer demand – a good thing in some ways, but it doesn’t translate well in terms of revenue.  You have to be able to deliver product to turn a profit on it.  I am baffled as to how an automaker that delivered 80,000 cars can be worth more than one that delivered 10M, even if the latter isn’t exactly on the cutting edge of style or technology.

Musk himself is a visionary, no doubt.  But I think his experiments with spaceflight are the demented fulfilment of his childhood fantasies, and might hurt his ability to carry Tesla’s momentum.  Other automakers are playing catch-up, but they have pretty good war chests, and an army of repeat buyers.  It will be tricky, I think, to keep Tesla sustainable.

Comment: According to the most recent timeline: 
9:59 p.m. Hotel security guard is shot 
9:59-10:05 p.m. Gunman fires at maintenance worker who finds injured security guard, worker tells hotel dispatchers to call police and report a gunman on the 32nd floor 
10:05 p.m. First shots are fired on crowd 
10:12 p.m. Two officers arrive on the 31st floor and determine gunfire is directly above them 
10:15 p.m. Last shots fired by gunman 

The most crucial detail, as far as LVMPD's reaction time, isn't about when the security guard got shot but rather,  when exactly did the maintenance worker notify hotel dispatchers about the gunman. Could it possibly be that he contacted them near 10:05 p.m., just seconds before the gunman opened fire on the crowd? That would have given the first responders under 7 minutes to receive the call, rush over to the hotel and ride the elevator up 31 floors. Another crucial question: When did the security guard notify hotel dispatchers of the gunman? Was it after the fact?

Comment: As long as the priority is pork over getting our people what they need, we run into this issue. We have a decent military budget but it is typically used for economic development or it is being frittered away to buy votes.  

The CPFs and 280 Class destroyers were custom designed for our waters so any added cost is understandable. The Harry deWolf class of vessels, however, are essentially a copy of the Norwegian Svalbard class. Ours cost over $700 million each for reasons that are not clear. The Norwegians paid $80 million each.  Irving Shipbuilding was awarded $288 million design contract for the vessel while the design of the Svalbard and similar patrol ships within other countries was one-tenth of that. No explanation or justification.   

Although I'm not a fan of our procurement system, it's hard to buy equipment when, as a project manager, you know the taxpayer is not only being ripped off but any sound procurement decision will be overruled by pork barrel politics.

Comment: This is incredibly depressing. I've never heard of such a one-sided deal before. The Europeans benefit (no need to explain) as do the Americans (new manufacturing to be done in the US, on a product that is already something like 52% sourced from the US). It is hard to see how this is not the beginning of the end of Bombardier, and with it Canada's aerospace industry, given that any upside from Bombardier's massive investment will flow 50% to one of its largest competitors. 

It brings into stark focus the disadvantages of building any business in a strategic sector in a small country like Canada that can be so easily pushed around by its major customers. Not sure what the solution is for Canada, but with so few large companies and particularly industrial champions left, time might have run out to figure this out.

Comment: Is Toronto going through, now, what Vancouver went through years ago?

See, thing is, years ago folks in Vancouver started similarly scratching their heads, asking, hey, how come when you're taxed as a top-high-income local worker, paying income tax in the highest tax bracket, you somehow still are not earning nearly enough money to buy house in Vancouver, selling as they were (and still are) for dozens of times the average annual local income?

Well, the income tax officials in Ottawa actually proved useful for the data that explained much of Vancouver's situation. They examined incomes being claimed in those million-dollar-plus houses of the day, and guess what? So many of them were claiming incomes around the poverty level!

Yes, claiming incomes so low that the breadwinners should not even have earned enough to pay the property taxes each year!

And then the "eureka" moment, realizing that money earned overseas, mainly in China and Hong Kong, was buying up the houses en masse...

Comment: My own manufacturing business (which exports millions of dollars worth of ten to twenty dollars a unit consumer products, to the US) has implemented new technologies and cut our electricity use by more than half.

Unfortunately, prices have risen somewhat more, but the price increases were a great incentive and we are, in real terms, only paying a little more. Worth it I think,  to cut the thousands of deaths and serious illness caused by fossil fuel electricity generation. And of course, to contribute to a cleaner future.

However, we took no advantage of readily available taxpayer funds, as it is hardly appropriate to give businesses welfare, towards what it should be doing anyway - improving efficiency and productivity.

And no, we are not crying, wailing, gnashing our teeth and calling for Wynne to be strung up, etc. etc. Nor are we blaming others. We're grown ups and can handle it. And we did.

Have a great day!

PS: I've never voted Liberal in  my entire sixty five years.

Comment: Its time the popular press stoped misrepresenting what the research actually shows. A number of studies show that while sleep periods may shift by two hours when children hit puberty, that is a shift with respect to their existing cycle. The research also indicates that the cycle is easily manipulated, and in a place like Alaska is almost entirely artificial.

In fact, most sleep clinics associated with major medical or academic institutions have a list of recommendations for helping teenagers get up when they should, including shutting down all electronics and dimming the lights....  at about 8 pm ;-)  No caffeine after 4:00 pm.  No alcohol or nicotine. Regular exercise.  Avoid naps but no more than an hour nap during the day.  Maintain the same sleep schedule on weekends.

And that all means that if your child is having trouble waking up in the morning, its likely because the discipline during the day is inadequate ;-)

Comment: Rules like publishing the data to show a safety value for enforcement cameras ARE absolutely critical to the public.  Failure of the city to follow those rules should void every camera ticket during the periods of non-compliance.  Citizens are bound to follow the law and SO are our governments.  The lawsuit should prevail.

WHY is this important?  It is because the primary purpose for ticket cameras is revenue, not safety. The cameras are for-profit business partnerships between governments and for-profit ticket camera companies.  In most cases, truly unbiased analysis of the data will show little or no safety value - and maybe reduced safety.

It is critical for the public to see the data to be able to object to the for-profit revenue programs and demand they be ended when they do not improve safety.

James C. Walker, National Motorists Association

Comment: I thought weed had a shelf life? 
Cannabis can have an indefinite shelf life, but only if all of the proper conditions have been met. For cannabis to truly stand the sands of time, one must not only handle each process of the growth and harvest cycle carefully, but also store the cannabis properly. If all of these conditions are met, one could be enjoying their favorite strain 10 years from now with little quality degradation.

Unfortunately, not all cannabis is cultivated with this level of precision and since consumers can’t control the quality of their cannabis before it reaches their hands, having the ability to identify mishandled cannabis that is typically labeled “old” or “bad” is an imperative last line of defense. After all, nobody wants to puff a bowl of bone dry and/or moldy ganja.

Comment: You end this post with "Aloha," yes there is clearly no Aloha in your words, which are misinformed and slightly offensive.  Do you know anything about the NOAA Fisheries Observer Program?  I suggest you call up John Kelley, the Pacific Islands Regional Office Administrator for the program and talk story with him about what it is the NOAA Observer Program does.  FYI: the Observer Program is responsible for one of the only and the largest, most comprehensive data sets on the pelagic fisheries of this region that exists. They are the people on the ground who collect all of the data that then goes in to stock assessments - the basis of the entire scientific process for these fisheries.  Furthermore you are misinformed about the nature of the Hawaiian Longline Fishery and where "the scientists" stand - if you ask ANY Fisheries Scientist at NOAA, they will tell you it is one of most (and best) regulated and sustainable commercial fisheries in the world.

Comment: I was glad to hear Jerry Howarth was back in the booth. It was he and Tom Cheek in the early Eighties that kept me as a fan during those years when the Jays didn't have much to celebrate. He taught me that you could appreciate the game, even if you lost. And in those days we lost quite a bit. During the '84-'85 campaign, I was living in Colombia, and enjoying winter ball. The Blue Jays organization sent me a box filled with Jays paraphernalia and I proudly passed it around and covered every public bus with Blue Jay stickers. Upon my return to Toronto, and taking my seat along the first base side, Jerry gave me a shout out at the game. One of the proudest moments of life came that day, and I attribute it to Jerry Howarth. Nothing but class! Thanks Jerry! Can't wait to hear, "and the Jays are in flight"!

Comment: My employees are all female, and have licensing requirements that must be met in order to keep their professional standing. This constitutes hours of practice, typically measured over a three year basis. If they have two kids, typically 2 years apart, with 18 months of leave, they will lose their professional standing and be forced to do remedial education to regain their standing. 

Typically I employ 8 women. I have paid for all their continuing education and advanced credentialing, allowing them to become more valued and appreciated employees. This amounts to thousands of dollars each year. Over the past 17 years of my practice, they have had 19 maternity leaves.

Aside from recruitment and training costs, forcing me to hire redundant employees, the biggest challenge with mat leave is the inflexibility of the EI system. The employee needs the flexibility to work on a part time basis during the mat leave to maintain licensure without sacrificing their licensure and my business.

Comment: First, you have to consider where China came from in this recent industrialization boom.  They were essentially a 3rd world farming community.  They had little experience with manufacturing, so their "knowledge" of the ramifications of the manufacturing industry was very limited....kinda like us in the early 1900's.

All that said, I've watched them come up to speed very quickly.  In the 1990's, when we were pushing manufacturing into Mexico, we tested the waters in China and it was a train wreck.  Now?  They have some of the quickest, cheapest, high tech manufacturing with full quality control systems.  And, their government is a big part of the clean-up push.

More Americans should travel, inclusive of there.  What we're told and our stories that circulate among our culture are largely false.  we do a disservice to many foreign cultures because of that.

Comment: Our family has been involved in the commercial fishing in Alaska since the mid 60's.  We ran across many southern built fishing boat that were poorly built.  I am biased toward Northwest built boats as that is what our family has owned. I believe in most cases they were better designed and better built but of course more expensive. I look at this way if you want a boat to last 20 years have it built in a southern yard where they pay the welders $20.00 a hour or if you want the boat to last 50 years have it built in the Northwest.

 If you look at the builders of the original fleet of Alaska State Ferries many built in the early 60's and still going you will see they were built in ether the Northwest or in Wisconsin.   There is a another ferry in the Northwest called the Coho running between Port Angles and Victoria that is nearly 60 years old and still making round trip everyday.  The Coho was the from the design that was used to build the older Alaska ferries.

Comment: Part two of some thoughts on Canadian history & its new usefulness.
The last 50 years or so, history and historical figures haven't been much of an issue for Canadians, mainly because they became irrelevant. We focused on the present--our acquisitive suburban lives, new forms of entertainment, freedoms from want and illness, new ways to communicate and new, compelling social causes. Nobody gave the past nor anything else associated with it (British Empire; traditional religion) much thought, let alone reverence. No one individual personified this shift more than untraditional Pierre Eliot Trudeau, who persuaded the Queen to sever an historic association between Canada and Britain.

Now history is useful again; a weapon wielded by the disaffected, the denigrated and disillusioned. It's been used to CHANGE our country; not to foster conformity, but to celebrate--and champion--diversity, to prove to ourselves that we are BETTER now than before. So, statues topple...and names change.

Comment: I think "Democracy" is a mis-used term.  We don't have a democracy, we have a Constitutional Republic in which we democratically elect some of our representation, but not all of them.  And our government doesn't operate by majority rule due the the Separation of Powers, our bi-cameral Congress that gives less populated states more power in the Senate, and a Supreme Court that isn't elected by popular vote.  These, and the Electoral College, were put in the Constitution for the explicit purpose of mitigating "democratic tyranny," which is when a self-interested majority tramples on the rights of individuals and minorities, such as the 15% who currently pay 85% of the taxes.

This country didn't become great because of universal suffrage.  It became great because of the Bill of Rights that was put there to protect individuals and minorities from majority rule.  Many countries have the right to vote, but don't protect minorities or religions from the tyranny of the majority.

Comment: We have seen time and time again, these cases get solved where there is behind the scenes diplomacy. Fact is we have little or no sway in a country from which we pulled out diplomats.  So we depend on other governments who may have their own issues to deal with. Comment: Mostly about insurance, what this article didn't address is the higher cost of virtually every medical procedure in Alaska (compared U.S. generally).  Part of the higher cost is attributable to our small towns spread across vast distances, quashing hope of economies of scale.  Thus, no HMOs in AK.  But another part of the higher cost is that doctors, clinics and hospitals charge much more in Alaska than they could for the same procedure in the Lower 49.  Read T. R. Reed's The Healing of America, in which he describes other countries' systems where doctors cannot legally charge more than a set fee for a procedure.  Medicare comes close to that, but, until we have a single payer U.S. system, not everyone is on Medicare, so those who must buy insurance policies get shafted by the insurance companies, which make bank off of Alaskans.  Remember the recurring Medicare "fix" because AK's procedure costs exceed Medicare allowable costs by so much?  This article only addresses one aspect.

Comment: Re: supervision of registered offenders: Those on parole or probation are supervised pretty carefully. Of course, the quality of supervision varies. Many jurisdictions entrust this work to officers especially trained for it. I think they generally do a great job. I'm biased in that I have a good friend who recently retired from that work. I know how hard he worked and how terrible he felt when one of his guys messed up in any way, let alone re-offended -- which over the years, a few did. Even after probation/parole, recidivism remains low for registered offenders in part, I think, because they've learned how to live safely, and in part because the registration is itself a kind of supervision. I'm not convinced that locking up priest-offenders together is the best way to respond to this problem; though for some of them it probably is. I think most of them, like most of the other 750,000 offenders, can and should live well in the community, with the appropriate supervision and support.

Comment: Okay, the 5 refineries in Washington state use 550,000 b/d, all of which comes in by tanker.
The new pipeline will bring 550,000 b/d down to the coast, all of which goes out by tanker.
And ... tankers are BAD.
So, if every barrel of oil in the Washington refineries gets supplanted by a barrel from the new pipeline .. presto ... no tankers at all. Tankers are bad and none would be needed out and none would be needed in.
But to  make this work, you need the KM pipeline. 
The simple fact is that you cannot supplant tanker volumes coming in unless you have oil available to supplant it with.
That helps Washington state, that helps BC, that helps Alberta, that helps Canada.
Build the damn pipeline. if you think logically, it is the only realistic way to save our coasts for good.

Comment: Your statements are ignorant in both anthropology and zoology.  
In Anthropology
Prior to agrarian systems (10,000 years ago) humans lived in nomadic groups for 1oo's of thousands of years and worked cooperatively to provide for each other, the groups were voluntary  associations.  Food was shared with the whole community, even if  the hunter got the beast, he shared with all.  It was not a constant state of war, nor do animals live in a constant state of war.  

The fight or flight response (stress response was designed for minutes and hours), not, months, and  years of stress.  Please  read some recent books anthropology and biology, before stating natures principles.  (Recent because science is constantly improving our understanding)

The economic system, capitalism, we have today based on resource ownership and rents is not natural and is a recent development of the last 200 years, it does not characterize how humans cared for each other during most of our evolution.

Comment: The primary drivers of why people choose to attempt suicide are related to anomie and other social, economic, and cultural factors. Which is what sound research, not begun, as is most of Hemenway's, with the premise that lawful gun ownership is a social ill and generalizable risk and thus the methodology used must be designed to support that thesis, consistently finds.

That a given suicidal person, driven to that point by those risk factors, will choose the most lethal means available to them is almost tautological. As any unbiased comparison of our overall suicide rates with those of other developed, yet more gun restrictive, nations shows.

On a practical side, 70%+ of firearm suicides in the US are adult, non-prohibited, male gun owners (conversely, the rate for teens (under 20) all means is <3 per 100k). Competent, autonomous adults can't in practice be affected by any proposed firearm type nor access restrictions, so I'm not sure what policy changes would help the big picture.

Comment: "Implementation of the 15% foreign buyers tax helped put the brakes on runaway prices here in metro Vancouver."  

"Helped"? Maybe.  How much?  Well...tax went into effect in September.  Vancouver area prices were in decline since June--three months before implementation date.  AFTER the tax was imposed, foreign-buyer deals spiked significantly between September and December.  Prices didn't seem to matter. 

What happened after New Years is also interesting: number of foreign buyer deals fell significantly, two months running.  Can't wait to see stats in March.  Oh, and that's not all that reportedly fell: influx of foreign capital?  Down significantly, too.  And what will the trickle-down on THAT scenario be, I wonder, as BC enters an provincial election campaign? 

(Stats Source: betterdwelling.com, April 2, 2017)

Comment: Have you ever tried to navigate an ordinary day without showing your identification? I have to show mine at the bank and the airport, to cash a check, if a cop stops me for a taillight, to get on base, to pick my kid up at school, to fill a prescription ... and those are just the items I can think of off the top of my head. I show my ID to someone on average every other day.

In fact, in Alaska, you can't register to vote without showing photo ID. My 18-year-old son recently registered on line and he had to give his driver's license number, which has a photo attached to it. He also had to show that ID when he was randomly stopped by a cop recently for walking while young.

So, to say that people are having their right to vote infringed by requiring photo ID at the polls is ridiculous. You need photo ID just about everywhere you go in any given day. Why would you leave it at home when you go vote? The vast majority of us drive to the polls, therefore we should have ID on us.

Comment: > These drafters also did not believe in direct election of individuals to Parliament.... we can only vote for a political party! Why was that?
That actually had a solid reason, as negotiators like Roelf Meyer and Neil Barnard had explained before. The ANC had a legitimate concern that, with constituency voting, we would end up with  electoral islands based on past appartheid spatial laws. To an extent, of course, this happened anyway -but at least there isn't a guy in parliament whose sole purpose is to keep the people of Ventersdorp happy by reintroducing the group areas act every two weeks (knowing it will be shut down but it's what they would like).
That said, I don't quite agree with the solution. The problem was real, but this system has it's own problems which are also pretty bad. 
I would have preferred the N.A. to follow the mixed model we use at the municipal level. Half the seats being party seats and half being constituency seats.

Comment: It’s one thing to pardon a criminal out of a sense of mercy or on the belief that he has paid his debt to society.
It’s trickier when the president pardons someone who violated the law in pursuit of governmental policy, the way George H.W. Bush pardoned Iran-Contra participants, including Caspar Weinberger and five others.
But it would be an altogether different matter if Trump pardoned Arpaio for willfully refusing to follow the Constitution and violating the rights of people inside the U.S.
Impeachment is the only constitutional remedy for dealing with a president, writes Feldman, "who abuses the pardon power to break the system itself."

Comment: The Canadian FPTP system has served the country well for almost 150 years. It is the system used by the strongest, most robust democracies in the world; namely the UK and the US. It enables checks and balances on the major parties so that the country proceeds largely down the middle of the road. Proportional representation systems are the hallmark of emerging democracies and welfare states. Under FPTP,  typically new leaders, such as Trump or Trudeau or Cameron, are elected because the voters are focused on throwing out the old leaders and governing parties.

Comment: The coal Colorado gets from the open pit mines in Wyoming is cheaper than the coal mined in tunnels back East, which makes our electricity production from coal about the same as from natural gas, depending on the commodities market prices on any given day.  It's probably why Colorado is still producing about 60% of our electricity from coal.  Not much return on investment spending millions to convert to natural gas if it isn't going to save much, if any, money.

Germany went "all in" on wind and solar, and the Germans spend three times as much for their electricity  as we do.  It's a bitter pill to swallow to admit you've made a huge mistake ... so they don't admit it.

Comment: It could be a good time to review federal travel regs.  Many are pennywise & dime foolish.  The FTR mandates the cheapest option, but usually not the most cost effective one.  Saving $5/day on car rental, but having to spend $45 in labor to cover the time needed to get to an off airport location.

I'm not going to defend or decry this situation.  Commercial air travel is not reliable.  Every time I've had to fly to a meeting & traveled the same day, I've missed the meeting.  Anymore if I have travel to a meeting, I go the day before & incur hotel, meal & car costs in addition to air fare.

I thought I might get thrown off one plane when I asked a flight attendant why the folks they were holding plane for were more important than me.  She did not like that.  BTW, I missed the meeting I was traveling for, despite having a scheduled arrival time several hours before the meeting.  I think a Cabinet level secretary has more important things to do than wait 5 hrs for a plane to leave.

Comment: Other teams now use the Oregon read option to one degree or another and thus practice against it weekly all season long.  This practice allows defenders to learn the intercept angles necessary to make solid tackles and linemen learn how to defeat the blocking.  This eliminates the big advantage Oregon used to have, that being the element of teams being unfamiliar with the offense with only one week to prepare for it.  Competitors have also adopted the "Tempo" , use it regularly and thus are in better shape to slow it down. Linebackers are smaller and faster and quicker thanks to Oregon"s scheme and reduce the effectiveness of the Oregon scheme. Essentially, Oregon has taught their competitors how to defend them as most have copied parts of their offense.  Oregon has taught competitors how to beat them.  The scheme also requires a very skilled QB with a very high  accuracy and fast feet. These are very hard to find. Recruit some bigger lineman would help, as Oregon undersized on line.

Comment: Generally, citizen-initiated ballot measures are only voted on at general elections in November of even-numbered years.
BUT TABOR allows for tax or bonding issues to be voted on in odd-numbered years.
There is considerable debate among all sorts of groups whether to try an odd-numbered year ballot measure or wait for the next general election. Odd-numbered year ballot issues are sort of like special elections: Only the truly motivated show up. Whereas, in general elections, a much broader pool of people shows up. That plays different ways to different groups.
But! Colorado now has all-mail balloting which goes out to every registered voter, and that throws the standard political calculus right out the window.

Comment: Understanding the current economy is fairly straight forward and doesn't depend on 'the gods of economics' like Keynes. 

The basic problem goes back to Ronald Reagan who shifted taxation from income tax to corporations. The 'progressive tax' on the rich kept the 'economic divide' in check and provided enough taxation to pay for government. 

Once Reagan's tax changes of 1968 went through, the rich were no longer taxed significantly on their income which started growing (while jobs stagnated). Then they discovered 'globalization' which allowed them to set up companies around the world and have the corporate tax paid there (at much lower levels) with the profits becoming income to the rich (who didn't pay much on it). This brought an outflow of jobs from the US (mostly reflected in 'workplace participation, not 'unemployment numbers).

Comment: Civil Beat appears to be a very easy fish to catch when the topic is GM, pesticides or Big Ag, and should more carefully inspect the bait before getting hooked. 

Any path to action has to consider what was found rather than just focusing on what wasn’t found:

The UH study on pesticide drift sampling of air at and near public locations for over a year found only tiny traces of a couple of pesticides; 

HDOA’s good neighbor database does show how much, how often and what kinds of pesticides were applied, and 93% of the amount applied was less acutely toxic than aspirin, and; 

Analysis of domestic water on Kauai found pesticides could not be detected. 

These findings are solid and significant for informing any action plan. An earlier study also found that urban areas on Oahu had the highest number of different pesticides, implicating non-agricultural sources. 

That no evidence of harm was found should not be maddening to CB – it may be related to some of the evidence that was found.

People of faith are just like people everywhere - the majority are kind, considerate, and reasonable. Some have to be right about everything, even impossibly arcane details (like the age of the earth). Their faith is fragile - the smallest chink in their insular logic destroys their illusion of total understanding. Bones? Fossils? Impossible!

Comment: We are all avoiding is that these shenanigans are the fault of the party system.  Were Canadian party leaderships decided in the old tried and true British style upon which they were originally modelled, only MPs within caucus would have a say.  That is as it should be because those folks are the ones with intimate knowledge of the strengths and weaknesses of each candidate, and of their respect by their fellow MPs.  Requiring party leaders to be chosen this way from among sitting MPs is an excellent practice.  One member one vote hinges on celebrity and has brought the wrong leaders regularly to the major parties. Of course, a better solution is a party-less system of Consensus Government as practised up North..  Voters would only focus on electing their local representative from among a list of Independent candidates.  This results in a better form of representation, with all MPs' having equal say. Now, in numerous instances, we could see a chimp elected in party strongholds.

Comment: Phillip, you dressed your rather lengthy response up in plenty of fancy terminology, however to an educated reader, you have actually erred on several levels.

Let us examine that the books didn't appear until (at least) hundreds of years after the events they claim to report. Comment: Today saw the September update of the Bank of Canada’s Canadian dollar effective exchange rate index (CERI), and of its monthly series for individual exchange rates. The CERI showed a 2.4% monthly increase, partly due to the September increase in the overnight rate, and a 7.3% increase from June, due also to the July rate increase. The loonie rose against the US greenback by 2.8% in September and against all other major currencies with the exception of the pound sterling, where there was a 0.4% drop. As the impact of this hike works its way through the economy it is bound to dampen consumer price inflation, which was already running much below the BoC’s 2% target rate, at 1.4%, in August. It shows just how delusional is the BoC’s argument that the September rate hike was a necessary preventive action to keep inflation from soaring above the target rate.

Comment: I am a Diclectin baby and a Diclectin mother--my mother took it throughout her pregnancy with me, and I took it throughout my first pregnancy, and for about half of my second pregnancy. My pregnancies defied the "morning" sickness label, and also defied assumptions that nausea and vomiting in pregnancy is an affliction of the first trimester only: I was sick all day every day for nine months for my first pregnancy, blessedly less in the second. I found that Diclectin reduced the nausea and vomiting but did not eliminate them. Once on Diclectin, I was vomiting only once or twice a day and the nausea was somewhat more intermittent than it had been. Not an easy spit-up, mind you, but full gut-wrenching vomiting. But that was a massive improvement over all day, and it helped me keep down enough calories to curb the weight loss and start putting on weight. I wouldn't say it was a wonder drug--I still felt far from normal--but it made it more bearable.

Comment: "In these markets where the lowest prices from power producers are sold first, natural gas and renewables are underbidding coal and nuclear."

This is factually inaccurate. The problem with nuclear is that those reactors have to produce power all of the time. Powering down costs tens of millions of dollars every time it's done. Operators must avoid that, and everybody knows it, so nuclear power is sold at rock bottom prices, prices so low that nuclear energy comes close to being economically impracticable. Meanwhile, coal and oil power plants can be started and stopped for much, much lower cost, so they tend to come into their own during peak demand, when prices are at their highest. So, if we were to set up a system where all power is sold at the same price regardless of generation technology, we'd pull the rug out from under coal.

Comment: Well, you're mostly right-- Alaska Airlines does want more gate space in Eastern cities.  But I think your assumption that if they buy VA then they get rid of the one airline that is keeping ticket prices down, so then they can raise them, is a little simplistic.  There are lots of factors influencing prices.  The author's mention of the JetBlue fare scheme is a great example.  Airlines have to strike a balance, and they are in the business of making money-- and as one commentor above correctly stated, fares have not kept pace with inflation and are actually lower than they *should* be based only on supply-demand.  Overall I think this merger will be a great thing for both companies-- I sincerely hope it is also for consumers.

CNBC's Jim Kramer is unmasked, once again, as the idiot he has always been.

Comment: Lars, even the language you use demonstrates the single purpose of a gun. Look closely at the term 'target practice.' Practice for what? The purpose of a gun is not to be a long-distance hole punch for a paper target, or to recycle glass from 100 yards. It's called PRACTICE because you're shooting at inanimate things to become proficient at hitting and killing living beings. When talking about home 'protection' the guns aren't being used as doorjams or fire extinguishers. 'Protect themselves' is another way of saying 'injure or kill a threat to your family.'

A gun is a tool, and that's nothing to be irrationally afraid of, but any rational person recognizes that the purpose of this particular tool is to kill living things. Don't try to sugarcoat it or pretend it isn't, it weakens any pro-gun argument you might have by making you seem disingenuous.

Comment: Bingo! The parallel case back East is the destruction of the tallgrass prairies of the Great Plains. The living land was ploughed to death and transformed into a lifeless medium for chemical fertilizer, GM seed stock, herbicides and pesticides, a kind of "zombie soil".  

Shallow rooted monoculture generally produces huge crops, but it doesn't keep the soil in place, so erosion is an issue; in some places subsidence is as much as six feet. 

Here in Oregon it strikes me that the biodiverse original growth that was logged out has been replaced by a kind of "zombie forest" of tree plantations, clearcuts and logging roads. Like movie zombies, the zombie forest greatly resembles the living one--if you don't look at it too close--but every fire season it tries to kill us. 

All the burns this summer are going to play hell with runoff this winter, I'd imagine, with greater possibility of killer mudslides and landslides. We've murdered the land, but, like movie monsters, it's coming back.

Comment: I disregard what you said because it is hearsay from an unidentified person. Anybody can claim anything on this site. No thinking person would accept an anonymous source in a newspaper article or a court of law, so why should we accept it here?

There are a handful of regular posters on this site who post under their real names and have verifiable credentials. When they write something pertinent to their field of expertise, I pay attention. I might not always agree, but I do take it seriously.

I am deeply grateful for the service and sacrifice of our military veterans, and if you are one then I am indeed grateful to you. But, no, I don't take such claims at face value from nameless, faceless posters on message boards. I'm sorry you take offense at that.

As for "armchair quarterbacking," this board exists to express opinions. I've done so. Agree or disagree as you like. Peace.

Comment: You can't balance the budget by continually increasing the military budget and cutting the top marginal tax rate both of which Trump is trying to do. The top marginal tax rate during the boom years of the 50's was 91%. In 1964 Congress and LBJ reduced it to 70% then in 1981 Congress and Reagan reduced it further to 50% and reduced it again in 1986 with an effective rate of 28.5%. This continual reduction of taxes on the richest Americans under the guise of creating more jobs, "trickle down" economics, has contributed to our budget deficits and exacerbated the income disparity in America. George HW Bush famously called it "voodoo economics". This budget cuts taxes on the rich once more. Can we not learn from history that cutting taxes on the rich doesn't work? "Those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it" - George Santayana

Comment: Quick fact check - The 2nd sentence of this article is false, and this is important given that the rest of the article is largely premised on this falsehood:

"The measure would impose a 2.5 percent tax on gross receipts of companies with more than $25 million in sales per year in the state."

Correction: Measure 97 addresses corporate MINIMUM taxes, not the corporate tax rate, which currently is and will remain 6.6% for the first $1M in taxable revenue and 7.6% for every dollar over $1M in taxable revenue.  Measure 97 adjusts the top tiers in the existing corporate MINIMUM tax table. While leaving the minimum the same for all companies grossing up to $25M a year, it raises the MINIMUM tax by 2.5% for each dollar of gross sales in Oregon over $2.5M. 

If businesses' corporate taxes are over this minima, their taxes are unchanged. The minimum gradually increase; it's not a "cliff." i.e., a business with $100M gross sales new MINIMUM tax is about 1.9% of gross sales in Oregon.

Comment: The objectors to Humanae Vitae never reached the point where they could write of "correction" or "heresy" since both of these have an implicit reference to the constant teaching of the Church.  There was an extra step for HV dissenters since it looked like they were asking for a break from tradition.

After Humanae Vitae there was vigorous discussion.  Which is still ongoing, to some extent.

Some made the clericalist appeal to authority.  But that time around the dissenters counted in their number the in-crowd, the Massimo Faggiolis and James Martins of their day (who could, like M. Faggioli, sometimes substitute snobbery for argument and get away with it.).  They started from a position of strength and moved to one of weakness due among other things to the development of analytical Thomism (didn't Liz Anscombe contribute?) and the further presentation of the Theology of the Body.  Advances in biology and medicine further strengthened the argument in favor of HV.

Comment: Absolutely true, what most don't seem to grasp is that at least one generator is essentially running 24/7 at any given time in any given community (regardless of wind).  Small loads such as light bulbs don't mean much in these small rural utilities unlike those on the grid.  The thing that makes a real difference is if the largest loads in a village can be reduced, which are typically the appliances at the residential level and the washeteria / schools / fish plants at the commercial.  And that is where capturing the waste heat (mechanical energy or kWM) can really displace energy costs if it's redirected to a boiler via a heat loop.

Comment: Any comment which contains "you actually don't know your stuff" is uncivil. Personal assessments of other posters are always uncivil. 

A troll is one who posts a deliberately provocative message to a newsgroup or message board with the intention of causing maximum disruption and argument.

For example, were one to encounter a poster whose posts consist primarily of personal assessments of posters with whom they disagree, disparaging of authorities, mocking of public personages, and the like but lacking in citations to actual authorities, logical constructions designed to endorse or question a proposition, questions such as "could you provide an example", one might conclude that poster is posting with the intention of causing maximum disruption and argument.

Comment: The answer to your question "what has changed to make things more favorable for moose" might just be pretty simple.  Sometimes, people who died decades ago used to tell stories about it.  When a moose came into the country it was hunted down, killed and eaten.  

Animals like moose were not able to gain a foothold.  Their population cycles would be very, very long, and dependent on a collapse in predator populations, including humans. With the arrival of imported food sources and game management, populations are protected during their down cycles, and thus have a good foothold for the upswing; evening out the "see-saw" of nature.

Comment: Many readers here will not like this, but hear me out:

We can complain all we want about fake news, but unless we insist that facts and truth are by their nature objective, which is to say not subject to what we want it to be.

Consider the recent assertions that have been commonly accepted around transgenderism.  The notion we appear to be required to accept is that the internal perception of gender must overrule the physical reality of our bodies.

When it comes to responsible consumption of news media, avoiding confirmation bias, don't you think?  But how can we possibly combat confirmation bias when we accept the basic anthropology of transgenderism, that is that perception of reality is more important than an objective assessment of reality?

We can't have it both ways.

Comment: I seem to remember reading quite a few anti-Trump articles in the last year or two in this newspaper (some written by this columnist) and other Canadian media sources. Diversity of opinions can have true value in a democracy, but such diversity is largely absent from Canadian media, and most U.S. media outlets I am familiar with, these days. It is not just the often simplistic way in which the stories are covered, and the obvious bias of many so-called journalists, that are troubling, but also the fact that many important stories are either completely ignored or covered very briefly because they don't fit comfortably within the preferred media "narrative", while other stories are overemphasized to a ridiculous extent because they confirm the biases of the journalists and editors in charge of covering them.

Comment: There was another missile crisis in 1962 when the Soviet Union was constructing missile launch sites in Cuba and bringing in missiles that could easily reach the U.S. 90 miles away.  President Kennedy ended that in October 1962 by ordering a naval blockade of Cuba.  Blockades are considered acts of war, so Kennedy called it a “quarantine.”  It worked.  Soviet ships heading to Cuba with missiles turned back to Russia and missiles already in Cuba were removed.  North Korea has shown that sanctions do not work.  A quarantine of North Korea just might do it.  Nothing in and nothing out by sea.   Yes, the poor people of North Korea will suffer, but perhaps no more than they have suffered since the Communists seized power in the 1940s.  And yes, a sea quarantine will place a great burden on China and Russia that border NK, but that should not matter because they created this monster.  It just might be enough to get China and Russia to cure NK's madness.

Paxton Lynch, the plodding, Clodsdale and No. 1 draft pick, could not nor could Kyle Sloter, a small-school talent who played big-time ball.

Against the Chargers, Siemian played like a second-year starter.
Against Dallas, a magnificent overall performance by the Broncos and a superb defensive attack sent the Cowboys reeling. It was a vintage TrevorBig production.
Then Denver fell as flat as the coastal plain of the Lone Star Republic against Buffalo. Denver's lack of scoring glowed most brightly with a second-half output of three points by the D-town team. TrevorLittle.
And, so, the hated Raiders came bumping into town.
They left with a few new bumps.
Denver's heroic Justin Simmons stole the game.
Siemian, though, failed/transformed into ChickenLittle.
It is ChickenLittle season.
